Desired Outcomes/Outcome Measures •Prevention/management of pressure sores –Occurrence, size of pressure sores •Decreased pain –V AS, 0–10  scale, or SCI pain inventory •Increased patient knowledge about SCI –Patient satisfaction questionnaires •Spasticity management –PRISM, Modified Ashworth Scale, Penn Spasm Frequency Scale, Spinal Cord Assessment Tool for spasticity, V AS self-rated  scale of spasticity •Improved ROM –Goniometric measurements •Improved strength –MMT •Improved ADLs (including bowel/bladder programs) –Barthel Index –SCIM-III •Improved mobility and gait –FIM, WeeFIM –WISCI    –TUG test –10MWT –SCIM III •Improved endurance –6MWTwhere applicable –Arm ergometry exercise testing –Borg RPE •Improved balance –BBS, PBS, functional reach test •Increased independence, improved quality of life –SF-36 Maintenance or Prevention
synonyms: spinal cord injury: motor incomplete injuries
spinal cord injury: sensory incomplete injuries
anatomical location body part affected: Vertebrae, spinal cord; body part affected depends on level of lesion and its location within the spinal cord

Injury in the cervical region of the spinal cord results in tetraplegia (preferred terminology), also called quadriplegia –Upper and lower extremities and trunk are affected –Viscera also are affected
Injury in the thoracic, lumbar, or sacral region of the spinal cord results in paraplegia –Trunk and lower extremities are affected –There may be visceral impairment
description: A spinal cord injury (SCI) is any injury to the spinal cord due to trauma or disease, including neoplasm, infection, degeneration, or vascular conditions. The neurological level of the lesion is defined as the most caudalsegment of the spinal cord with normal sensory and motor function(1)

Patients with incomplete SCI have preservation of some sensory and/or motor function below the neurological level, including in the lowest sacral segment(2) –A lack of any sensory or motor function in the lowest sacral segment, including anal sensation or voluntary contraction of the sphincter, is by definition a complete SCI
Tetraplegia is more common than paraplegia and accounts for 52% to 59% of SCIs(1)
Nontraumatic SCIs are generally less severe and almost always incomplete injuries(1)

The incidence of traumatic SCI is approximately 54 cases per million population in the United States (i.e., 17,700 annually), 53 cases per million in Canada, 19 to 24 cases per million in France and Spain, and between 12 to 14 cases per million in the Netherlands, Qatar, Ireland, Finland, and Australia(1)

Based on the degree of motor and sensory loss, the American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) classifies SCI into one of 5 categories of severity using the ASIA Impairment Scale (AIS) as follows: –A – Absence of any sensory or motor function in the sacral segments S4-S5 –B – Sensation is preserved in S4-S5,  but there is no motor function caudal to the lesion (specifically, caudal to 3 segments below the neurological level) –C – Sensation is preserved in S4-S5,  but more than half of the key muscles below the lesion have a muscle grade less than 3/5 –D – Sensation is preserved in S4-S5,  and more than half of the key muscles below the lesion have a muscle grade greater than or equal to 3/5 –E – Sensory and motor function are normal –A designates a complete lesion. B, C, D, and E designate incomplete lesions  -ASIA E implies that an individual can have a SCI without having any motor or sensory deficits that are detectable on standard neurological examination. Patients categorized as ASIA E may have subtle weakness, spasticity, pain, and/or certain forms of dysesthesia

S14.base: injury of nerves and spinal cord at neck level
S14.S14.0: concussion and edema of cervical spinal cord
S14.S14.1: other and unspecified injuries of cervical spinal cord
S14.S14.2: injury of nerve root of cervical spine

S24.base: injury of nerves and spinal cord at thorax level
S24.S24.0: concussion and edema of thoracic spinal cord
S24.S24.1: other and unspecified injuries of thoracic spinal cord
S24.S24.2: injury of nerve root of thoracic spine

S34.base: injury of nerves and lumbar spinal cord at abdomen, lower back and pelvis level
S34.S34.0: concussion and edema of lumbar spinal cord
S34.S34.1: other injury of lumbar spinal cord
S34.S34.2: injury of nerve root of lumbar and sacral spine

ICD-10 codes.T06.0: injuries of brain and cranial nerves with injuries of nerves and spinal cord at neck level
ICD-10 codes.T09.3: injury of spinal cord, level unspecified
ICD-10 codes.T09.4: injury of unspecified nerve, spinal nerve root and plexus of trunk
ICD-10 codes.T91.3: sequelae of injury of spinal cord (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference and not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Medicare has specific documentation requirements for mobility devices;these requirements are particularly stringent for power mobility devices

Many insurance companies consider robotic-assisted  rehabilitation of the upper limb and lower limb experimental and investigational for incomplete SCI because of insufficient evidence of its effectiveness. Check with patient’s provider
presentation signs and symptoms: Presentation varies depending on level and severity of injury –Primary symptoms are related to muscle paralysis, sensory impairment,and autonomic impairment, including bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction(9) –Other symptoms may be vague and nonspecific and can reflect a variety of underlying conditions, including bladder distension, urinary infection, autonomic dysreflexia, respiratory compromise, and pressure ulcers(9) -See Complications and associated conditions , below

Incomplete SCI syndromes –Central cord syndrome -The most common incomplete SCI -Caused by hyperextension in the presence of cervical spondylosis and spinal stenosis(2) -The upper extremities present with a greater degree of involvement than lower extremities; intrinsic hand function is last to return post injury(2) -Patient typically regains some ability to ambulate(2) -More than half of individuals will have spontaneous voiding and bladder emptying(2) –Anterior cord syndrome -Occurs in 2.7% of traumatic SCIs(2) -Often caused by flexion injuries(2) -Often a direct injury affecting the anterior region of the spinal cord by bone fragments or from damage to anterior spinal artery(6)  -Bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and motor function(2) -Deep pressure, proprioception, and light touch often are intact(2) (posterior columns of the spinal cord are spared) –Posterior cord syndrome -A rare incomplete SCI syndrome -The posterior spinal artery often is injured in this syndrome(2) -Patient presents with absent proprioception, two-point  discrimination, stereognosis, and vibration sense below the level of the lesion(2) -Light touch and pain sensation are intact(2) -Motor function and strength are preserved(21) -Patients have some ability to ambulate(21) –Brown-Sequard  syndrome -A rare incomplete SCI syndrome in which only one side of the spinal cord is damaged(2) -Frequently caused by gunshot wound or stabbing injury(2) -Ipsilateral loss of motor function and proprioception(2) -Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation(2) -Patients with Brown-Sequard  syndrome have excellent prognosis and usually can ambulate(2) –Conus medullaris syndrome -Typically caused by trauma and tumors(2) -Trauma affects the spinal cord in the sacral area as well as lumbar nerve roots (in the canal)(2) -Bladder and bowel dysfunction(19) -Minimal lower extremity weakness(19) -Sensory impairment is symmetrical in saddle area(19) –Cauda equina syndrome -Involves the lumbosacral nerve roots; the cord may be spared(2) -Asymmetrical impairment -Lower motor neuron injury(2) -Presents with flaccid paralysis with no spinal reflex(2) -Partial or complete loss of sensation(2) -Absent sacral reflex – affects lower urinary tract, distal bowel, and sexual function(6) -See Clinical Review…Cauda Equina Syndrome  ; Topic ID: T708499 for more information Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Traumatic SCI–Types of trauma that may result in SCI: motor vehicle accidents, falls, gunshot wounds, water accidents,and sportsinjuries(2)

Nontraumatic SCI–Causes of nontraumatic SCI-Pathological fracture-Cancer(3) (please see  Clinical Review…Spinal Tumor  ; CINAHL Topic ID: T708495)-Inflammation/infection(3)-Degeneration of the spine(3)-Vascular disturbance/bleeding(3)-Spinal column disorders (e.g., spinal stenosis)(2)-Motor neuron disease(2)-Transverse myelitis(1)-Syringomyelia(1)
pathogenesis: Traumatic SCI–Typically, acceleration-deceleration  incidents, which bring about extreme forces on the spinal cord and vertebrae, are thecause of the SCI. Types of forces/motions that lead to the breakdown of the spinal cord and surrounding structures includethe following(1):-Hyperextension-Hyperflexion-Axial loading-Compression-Rotation–The inflammation following the trauma is a significant contributing factor in the secondary damage to the spinal cord andimpacts patient outcomes(20)
risk factors: Traumatic SCI–Age-There is a bimodal distribution in incidence of SCI(1)-Incidence is highest among young adults and individuals > age 65–Sex-Male-to-female  ratio is equal until the age of 5 years, then begins to show a greater proportion of males. In the 16- to20-year  age range the ratio is approximately 80% male. With increasing age, the ratio begins to even out. After the ageof 65 years, women account for 44%(1)

Nontraumatic SCI–Can be caused by a variety of conditions, including(1):-spinal column disorders (e.g., stenosis, disc prolapse)-metabolic disorders-neoplasms-infections-inflammatory and autoimmune disorders-vascular disorders-motor neuron disease-drugs and toxins
complications and associated conditions: Cardiopulmonary – pneumonia atelectasis, ventilatory failure, DVT, pulmonary embolism, orthostatic hypotension, apneicbradycardia
Integumentary – injury due to pressure, shearing, moisture

Neuromuscular and musculoskeletal – spasticity, flaccidity, autonomic dysreflexia, contracture, heterotopic ossification,osteoporosis, spinal deformities–Long bone fractures are a common secondary complication of SCI due to loss of bone mass(15)-Lower extremities predominantly are affected, and fractures typically are low-energy  (i.e., fragility fractures)-Patients with lumbar lesions are affected more than those with cervical lesions, and the majority of patients havecomplete injuries
Genitourinary and gastrointestinal – urinary tract infection, ulcers, neurogenic bowel

overall contraindications precautions: Monitor for signs and symptoms of autonomic dysreflexia in patients with lesions at or above T6; the clinician should identify and remove precipitating factors if possible and seek emergent medical care.(1) The condition can be life-threatening(1) (please see  Clinical Review…Autonomic Dysreflexia in Adults  ; CINAHL Topic ID: T708491 for more information on this condition) Signs of autonomic dysreflexia(1) –Hypertension –Bradycardia –Flushing of face, neck, and shoulders –Pounding headache –Profuse sweating –Nasal congestion A distended bladder is the most common cause of autonomic dysreflexia. Other causes include pathology of the bladder and rectum, fecal impaction, and ingrown toenails(1) Although autonomic dysreflexia more commonly occurs in patients with complete injuries, approximately 25% of patients with incomplete injuries also are affected by it(1)
In the acute stage, therapy should focus on joint protection, positioning, and selective preservation of ROM (note: some tightening is indicated for the facilitation of functional tasks)

Patients are at increased risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).(1) If the patient has developed DVT, withhold mobilization and exercise of the affected extremities for 48 to 72 hours; obtain orders from physician prior to resuming exercise and mobilization
Orthostatic hypotension is common in individuals with SCI(1)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -How and when did the SCI occur? -What is the level of the lesion? -Does the patient have any complications and/or comorbid injuries (e.g., traumatic brain injury [TBI], musculoskeletal injuries, internal injuries)? -Does the patient have an identified incomplete SCI syndrome (e.g., central cord syndrome, anterior cord syndrome)?

course of treatment.medical management: Who is on the patient’s medical team? Upon onset of SCI, treatment consists of spinal immobilization(2) stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation fluid replacement management of hemorrhage if present assessment for head injury reduction of swelling around the spinal cord placement of nasogastric tube if ileus is present anticoagulation for the prevention of DVT surgery(1,2)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications have been prescribed; are they being taken? High-dose  steroids  provided during acute phase to assist in recovery and possibly limit damage to nervous tissue Tizanidine and baclofen used in the treatment of spasticity post injury; gabapentin may be used for chronic pain
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
The physician will also complete sensory testing of the anal area to determine if the lesion is complete or incomplete
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture), what they are being used for, and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document the patient’s post SCI rehabilitation to date. Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any aggravating factors for symptoms such as spasticity, pain, and fatigue
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if  pain   is present now and how much) -The SF-36  single pain interference question and the Multidimensional Pain Inventory (MPI) or Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) pain interference items can be used as outcome measures for pain interference after SCI
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Does the patient use a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) device? -Prevalence of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in patients with tetraplegia is reported to be 50%60%,  as compared to a prevalence of 4%9%  in the general population(1) -OSA can cause fragmentation of sleep, loss of restorative sleep, and increased sympathetic nervous system activity, which can result in excessive daytime sleepiness and hypertension
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document respiratory status (e.g., need for ventilator, supplemental oxygen), status of respiratory muscles especially diaphragm Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe  ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history If the SCI was nontraumatic, what condition was it caused by? What formal testing has the patient undergone? What surgical procedures has the patient undergone, if any?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders. Is there a history of substance abuse?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may have experienced

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: If the patient is young, how is the child able to negotiate the school/home environment? Can the adult patient negotiate work environment? Is the patient involved in any activities? Does the family/patient feel they have necessary support in place?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What ADLs can the patient perform? What assistive devices or adaptive equipment does the patient require? Determine the patient’s potential for use of technology
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Are caregivers able to provide support and necessary assistance? Can the patient access community resources?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting) •Anthropomorphic characteristics –Document patient’s height and weight and calculate BMI
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –Document assistive devices currently in place and ability to use them; are additional assistive/adaptive devices indicated? –Consider devices to assist with gait, bathing, toileting, and self-care,  as well as pressure-relieving  mattresses and cushions
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Evaluate balance in sit and stance, if able, utilizing the Berg Balance Scale (BBS), Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS), and/or Modified Functional Reach Test –The patient with an SCI may use compensatory strategies to sustain posture against gravity; however, these strategies can interfere with the patient’s ability to perform independent functional activities. For example, the patient who relies on upper extremity assistance to maintain balance in stance may be unable to reach out and use hands functionally
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Document vital signs at rest and during mobility; include rating of perceived exertion (RPE)
Patients with SCI are at risk for severe orthostatic hypotension(1)

Assess respiratory status -Patients with injuries above C4 may require ventilator support for respiration. Document need for artificial ventilation/ oxygen(2) -Assess which muscles of respiration have been impacted by SCI(2) -Monitor for signs and symptoms of atelectasis, pneumonia, or infection (such as increased temperature, change in respiratory rate, shortness of breath, increased heart rate, anxiety, and increased volume or change in consistency of secretions)(2) -Document respiration pattern and any accessory muscle use(2) -Forceful expiration and cough may be affected in patients with SCI depending on the lesion level.(2)Document cough ability and need for support during coughing(2)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess circulation and for signs of DVT. Assess bilateral pedal pulses Cranial/peripheral nerve integrity –Assess cranial nerve integrity –Peripheral nerve involvement (i.e., lower motor neuron lesion) results in flaccid paralysis rather than spastic paralysis – can have both(2) Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.) –Complete a functional assessment. The FIM, WeeFIM, or Spinal Cord Independence Measure (SCIM) may be used
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Evaluate gait as indicated –Walking Index for Spinal Cord Injury (WISCI)(4) -Created for the assessment of ambulation post SCI -The instrument factors in physical assist, assistive devices, and orthoses -Larger scores designate less impairment -Test includes 21 levels -Important to complete assessment in same environment each time for accuracy (e.g., indoors vs. outdoors, carpet vs. no carpet)  –Researchers who conducted a retrospective review that incorporated 284 patients with SCI found that the WISCI may be more comprehensive and more responsive to ambulation recuperation than other walking scales(5) –WISCI-II(6) -An amended version of the WISCI -Contains an ordinal scale -0 on the scale designates a nonambulatory status and a score of 20 designates that the individual can ambulate at least 10 m without physical assist or assistive devices –In a cross-sectional  study, researchers evaluated 3 timed walking tests in individuals with SCI and reported that the instruments were valid and reliable outcome measures in this population(6) -Evaluated tests -Timed Up & Go (TUG) test -10-meter  walk test -6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) -Evaluated tests were compared against the WISCI-II -Correlation between the evaluated tests and the WISCI-II  was good except for the circumstance when walking function was poor; the TUG test and the 10-meter  walk test reliability decreased in this circumstance –6MWT -Measures the distance walked in 6 minutes –10-meter  walk test -Measures the time required to ambulate 10 meters -Results of a research study indicate that the 10-meter  walk test has high inter-  and intrarater reliability(7) Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Assessments may include the Patient Reported Impact of Spasticity Measure (PRISM), Ashworth and Modified Ashworth scales, Spinal Cord Assessment Tool for Spasticity, V AS for spasticity, Penn Spasm Frequency Scale, and Wartenberg Pendulum Test
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Manual muscle testing (MMT) is essential and must be specific –Motor control assessment is appropriate when there is abnormal tone or lack of coordinated movement and when the patient cannot follow instructions for MMT
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess skin integrity, particularly over bony prominences
Measure and stage all wounds (e.g., location, depth, color, exudate)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Evaluate patient’s sitting posture in wheelchair seating system or in standing in ambulatory patients
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess bilateral upper and lower extremity active and passive ROM. Document bilateral muscle length for hamstrings, gastrocsoleus, biceps, triceps, and iliopsoas muscle groups
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Reflex testing –Evaluate bilateral upper and lower extremity deep tendon reflexes –Assess for presence of Babinski reflex and spinal reflexes (e.g., flexor withdrawal, crossed extension) Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing) –Assess ADLs using the FIM, WeeFIM, Barthel Index, or Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM) -The COPM designates areas of limitation in self-care,  leisure, and productivity(8) -Patient then rates significance of each limitation from 1 to 10 -Up to 5 noted problems are selected by the patient to be the goals of his or her rehabilitation program -Patients appraise their performance, and satisfaction with performance, in each of the 5 selected goals; scales of 1 to 10 are used -Average scores are collected for satisfaction and performance -Patient is expected to review goals and rank satisfaction and performance upon reassessments -Valid tool across various diagnoses and clinical settings and has shown test-retest  reliability; limited testing in patients with SCI
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Assess bilateral dermatomes for pin prick and light touch –Assess bilateral dermatomes for sharp-dull  discrimination, temperature, and proprioception as indicated –Refer to the physician’s report for information regarding sensation in the anal area
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Autonomic Standards Assessment Form(ASAF), Second Version(14) -The Autonomic Standards Committee of ASIA and the International Spinal Cord Society (ISCoS) developed the ASAF, an autonomic nervous system assessment tool to be included as part of the clinical evaluation of individuals with SCIheart rate, blood pressure, sweating, temperature regulation, and respiration -Lower urinary tract, bowel, and sexual function are scored on a 0 to 2point scale, with 2 being normal function and 0 complete loss of control; based on patient self-report –Medical Outcomes Study 36-Item  Short Form (SF-36) -Tool that can assist in tracking quality of life indicators post discharge from acute care setting -Eight domains including pain, physical function, mental health, social function, vitality, overall health perception, role limitation due to physical problems, and role limitation due to emotional problems -All scale scores extend from 0 to 100 (poor to excellent health state) –SF-12  Health Related Quality of Life questionnaire -Reduced version of the SF-36  containing 12 items -Studies have demonstrated high correlation to SF-36 -Two questions on SF-12  are inapplicable for individuals with complete SCI as they deal with stair climbing and ambulation –Needs Assessment Checklist (NAC)(10) -Created for patients with SCIADLs, bladder management, bowel management, skin management, mobility, community, wheelchair and equipment, psychosocial issues, and discharge coordination -4-point  rating scale; 0 denotes dependence and 3 independence -The checklist may be useful in therapeutic goal planning –Spinal Cord Independence Measure (SCIM) III(11)mobility (0–40),  self-care  (0–20),  and respiration and sphincter management (0–40) -The final score ranges from 0 to 100 points Wheelchair mobility –Evaluate wheelchair mobility and skills –The SmartWheel(12) -An assessment device that can be attached to the majority of standard wheelchairs -Device records amount of force put forth with every push, length and ease of every push, and push frequency -Data collected may be utilized as objective outcome data or for reimbursement –The SmartWheel Users’ Group (SWUG)(12) -Created a standard clinical protocol -Propelling a wheelchair over smooth tile -Propelling a wheelchair over carpet -Propelling a wheelchair up a ramp that complies with the requirements of the Americans with Disabilities Act -Performing a figure 8 on smooth tile -Average peak resultant force, velocity, push frequency, and stroke length -Group felt that each patient should complete a wheelchair velocity assessment first; minimum velocity for safe community propulsion must be attained (reportedly 1.06 m/s)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Assess if the patient is alert and oriented x 4 –Note affect; monitor for signs of depression or anxiety –Mini-Mental  Status Examination (MMSE) can be used to screen for cognitive impairment as indicated –Patients with concomitant TBI may require formal testing

contraindications precautions: decreased sensation; do not apply heat to areas of impaired sensation due to increased risk of burns
electrotherapy contraindications precaut: Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders or specific protocols

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions include: (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(13)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: With any SCI there is an obvious need for rehabilitation services once the patient is medically stable. The therapist’s role is critical in maximizing the patient’s functional independence as well as assisting the entire medical team in educating the patient on how to live with this life-altering condition
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out  (1) Spinal column disorders (e.g., stenosis, disc prolapse) Metabolic disorders (e.g., vitamin B12 deficiency, copper deficiency) Vascular disorder (e.g., hemorrhage, ischemia) Inflammatory and autoimmune disorders (e.g., multiple sclerosis, transverse myelitis, lupus) Drugs and toxins Neoplastic disorders Infection Motor neuron disease (e.g., amyotrophic lateral sclerosis) Syringomyelia
prognosis: Sacral sparing examination determines whether an SCI is classified as neurologically complete or incomplete, which is helpful to determine prognosis(22)
Most individuals with central cord syndrome will regain the ability to ambulate(2)
Individuals with anterior cord syndrome generally have a poor prognosis for the return of bowel and bladder control, hand function, and the ability to ambulate(2)
Typically individuals with Brown-Sequard  syndrome regain the ability to ambulate(2)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Social worker and/or counselor/therapist to assist with community resources and psychosocial needs Occupational therapist Respiratory therapist Orthotist V ocational rehabilitation specialist Recreation therapist Pain management specialist
treatment summary: Therapeutic exercises –Fitness guidelines for individuals with SCIs(23) -Cardiorespiratory fitness – participate in 20 minutes of moderate-  to vigorous-intensity  aerobic exercise 2 times per week -Strength exercise – perform 3 sets of strength exercise for each major functional muscle group at a moderate to vigorous intensity 2 times per week –Cardiometabolic guidelines for individuals with SCIs(23) -Perform at least 30 minutes of moderate-  to vigorous-intensity  aerobic exercise 3 times per week –Based on a 2017 systematic review of adults with chronic SCI, exercise improves cardiorespiratory fitness, power output, strength, and cardiometabolic health. The authors found low- to moderate-quality  evidence in support of the following guidelines(24): -Cardiorespiratory fitness, power output, and muscle strength can improve with 2–3 sessions/week of upper body aerobic exercise at a moderate to vigorous intensity for 20–40  minutes, plus upper body strength exercise (3 sets of 10 repetitions at 50%–80%  1-repetition  maximum for all large muscle groups) -Cardiorespiratory fitness, muscle strength, body composition, and cardiovascular risk can also improve with 3–5 sessions per week of upper body aerobic exercise at a moderate to vigorous intensity for 20–44  minutes –Increasing lower extremity strength and preferred walking speed can enhance walking speed and minimize disability –Eccentric resistance training improves eccentric and isometric strength in individuals with incomplete SCIs(26) -Eleven individuals with incomplete SCIs who were able to complete a 10-meter  walk assessment participated in the United States-based  study -Participants completed eccentric training on a lower body eccentric training resistance machine (2 times per week for 12 weeks) -Eccentric and isometric strength improved post training; daily step activity remained the same –Eccentric resistance training improves ambulatory capacity (i.e., walking mobility, speed, and independence) in individuals with incomplete SCI(29) -Based on a study in the United States -Participants performed eccentric training 2 times per week for 12 weeks –High-intensity  interval training (HIIT) does not result in greater physical capacity or activity levels than moderate-intensity  training (MIT) in ambulatory individuals with incomplete SCI(28)

Gait training –Authors of a 2016 systematic review found that there currently is insufficient evidence to determine the best clinical practice guidelines for locomotor training in the pediatric SCI population(16) -Six studies met inclusion criteria  -Results showed gains in distance, gait speed, walking independence, and participation; however, all were case studies and the lack of a controlled condition made it difficult to determine whether there was a cause and effect relationship between the outcome measures and the locomotor training –Guidelines for interventions to improve walking speed and timed distance(30) -For ambulatory individuals > 6 months post chronic stroke, incomplete SCI, or brain injury -strong evidence supports clinicians offering ambulatory training at moderate to high intensities or virtual-reality-based training to ambulatory individuals -weak evidence supports strength training, circuit training, or cycling training at moderate to high intensities; virtual-reality-based  balance training may also improve walking speed and distance -the following should not be performed to improve walking speed of distance (based on strong evidence):body-weight-supported  treadmill training (BWSTT), robotic-assisted  training, or sitting/standing balance training without virtual reality

BWSTT –Robotic-assisted  BWSTT is effective for improving peak fitness levels in persons with chronic motor incomplete SCI(17) -Based on a pilot prospective RCT in the United States that involved 18 individuals -The group that received robotic-assisted  BWSTT improved peak VO 2 by 12% during treadmill walking compared to 3.9% improvement in the control group that received a home stretching program –Intermittent hypoxia(IH) is a novel, noninvasive method to induce plasticity by strengthening spared pathways to motoneurons after incomplete SCI that is currently being investigated. Researchers in Chile found that IH with locomotor training improved dynamic balance in patients with incomplete SCI(18) -35 participants with ASIA grades C and D injuries received either IH or normal oxygen (placebo) during a BWSTT protocol -Participants completed 45 minutes BWSTT for 5 consecutive days followed by 3 times per week for 3 more weeks -Results indicate that IH combined with locomotor training improves dynamic, but not standing, balance in persons with incomplete SCI –Manually assisted body-weight-supported  locomotor training did not re-establish gait in individuals with chronic incomplete SCI without baseline walking ability(27)

Balance training –Semi-immersive  virtual reality (VR) therapy improves standing balance and upright mobility function in patients with chronic incomplete SCI(25) -Based on a study in South Korea, 10 subjects with chronic incomplete SCIs completed VR therapy 30 minutes a day, 3 days per week for 6 weeks -All outcome measures improved significantly post-intervention.  Pre- and post-  intervention outcome measures included the following: -Balance measures – Limit of Stability (LOS), Berg Balance Scale (BBS) -Upright mobility function measures –TUG,  Activities-Specific  Balance Confidence (ABC) Scale, and WISCI-II

Spasticity –Spasticity can interfere with rehabilitation or ADLs, but can also be used for function. Spasticity may be used to assist with bladder emptying, transferring, or dressing. A balance between the detrimental and beneficial effects of spasticity should be sought

Electrotherapeutic modalities –Functional electrical stimulation (FES) during gait training in individuals with incomplete SCI is reported to improve ambulation by augmenting swing, increasing walking speed, and increasing lower extremity muscle strength(13) -FES may be used for dorsiflexion assist alone or in combination with FES to other muscle groups

Studies have shown that the combination of FES for gait and treadmill training can improve walking speeds on and off the treadmill, lower extremity motor scores, quality of life scores, WISCI scores, SCIM scores, and participation . maintenance or prevention: DVT prevention In combination with other medical treatments (e.g., anticoagulant medications), mobilization and passive exercise beginning as soon as the patient is medically stable may help to prevent DVT
